children.name: :4: The family is forced to leave Cordoba
children.data: In 1148 Cordoba was taken over by the intolerant dynasty of the Muwahhidun (Almohads), who by then ruled most of the Maghreb as well. The Almohads deprived the non-Muslim communities of their previous rights and persecuted them with threats of forced conversion or deportation. The Maimonides family, like many others, left Cordoba and began an extended period of wandering.

attachments.name: coin of Muwahidun ruler abd al-Mu'min.jpg

children.chronologicalName: The family is forced to leave Cordoba

children.name: :5: 1160-1165 Morocco - forced conversion
children.data:
In 1160 the family settled in Fez, Morocco which was also under the rule of the Almohads as well, where Maimonides witnessed terrible persecutions.

         It seems that during this period the family was forced to convert.

This is probably why sometime between 1160-1165 Maimonides wrote The Letter on Forced Conversions  which pardoned fake conversion to Islam in cases of forced conversion.  

         In Fez Maimonides continued studying medicine, mainly through apprenticeship.

children.name: :6: Pilgrimage to the Holy Land
children.data: In 1165 the Maimonides' family left for Palestine, which was ruled at that time by the Crusaders. They visited  Acre, Jerusalem and Hebron.

attachments.name: Christian van Adrichom's Map of Jerusalem in the Time of Jesus (1590) .jpg
attachments.location: A35916B5-7608-6F21-7BC9-A0335815B679\Christian van Adrichom's Map of Jerusalem in the Time of Jesus (1590) .jpg

attachments.name: Acre map, 17th century, Vesconte, Petrus.  Civitas Acon Sive ptolomayda.jpg
attachments.location: A35916B5-7608-6F21-7BC9-A0335815B679\Acre map, 17th century, Vesconte, Petrus.  Civitas Acon Sive ptolomayda.jpg

children.name: :7: The Family moves to Old Cairo (Fustat)
children.data: In 1166 the family settled in Fustat (old Cairo), then under Fatimid rule. The Fatimids were tolerant rulers, and their theology encouraged the study of philosophy. Maimonides, protected by the Fatimid rule, took to teaching Greek sciences and philosophy. During the first five years in Fustat, Maimonides completed his first major legal treatise, the Commentary on the Mishnah, a work that he composed over the long years of travels.
children.chronologicalName: The Family moves to Old Cairo (Fustat)

children.name: :8: Maimonides becomes Court  Physician of the Ayyubids
children.data:
Maimonides'  family made its living from commerce, and Maimonides was supported by his brother David who traded with India.

In 1171 Egypt was conquered by the Ayyubid dynasty.  Around the same time Maimonides'  brother David drowned drowned during a commercial trip to India, and Maimonides, sick with grief over his brother, was forced to begin work as a court physician for the royal family.

 

                 

During these years he wrote many important medical treatises, in which he sought to simplify and render more systematic the medical tradition of Galen (2ed cent') transmitted through the Muslim world. His treatises were translated to Latin during the 13th century and thus influenced medical knowledge in the medieval West.

attachments.name: Hanhagat ha-beriut (medical treatise) in Latin, Florence, 1481.jpg

children.chronologicalName: Maimonides becomes Court  Physician of the Ayyubids

children.name: :9: Appointed Head of the  Jewish Community
children.data:
During this period Maimonides was recognized as the highest spiritual authority of his time and served for some years also as head  of the Jewish community  in Egypt (Rais al-Yahud). His numerous legal and theological responses to queries from Jews in Egypt, the Middle East, and Europe attest to his local authority and international prestige.

The stability of Maimonides’ later life in Ayyubid Egypt enabled him to compose many treatises, including his two most important works: the Mishneh Torah  and the Guide to the Preplexed.

 

photos: The Ben Ezra synagogue, the ancient synagogue in old Cairo (Fustat), where Maimonides led the Jewish liturgy, also shown are the works of preservation and construction
children.chronologicalName: Appointed Head of the  Jewish Community

children.name: :10: His Death
children.data:
Maimonides passed away in 1204 in Egypt and was buried there, but early Jewish tradition claims that he had asked to be buried in the Holy Land and that his boned were brought to burial in Tiberias, where his tomb is still shown.

A very known Hebrew proverb in Maimonides' memory is "From moses to Moses there was none as great as Moses", meaning that from the biblical Moses to Moses son of Maymon (Maimonides), no one was their match in the leadership of the Jewish people and the knowledge of the Torah. This proverb was inscribed on his grave at Tiberias.

attachments.name: _From moses to Moses there was none as great as Moses_.jpg
attachments.location: 0E88C45C-353C-2D9C-D6C2-A2395A860B45\_From moses to Moses there was none as great as Moses_.jpg

children.name: Commentary on the Mishnah
children.data:
As in other scholarly fields, Maimonides broke new ground to write a commentary directly on the Mishnah.  Maimonides began composing his commentary  in 1161 while living in in Morocco and completed it in Egypt in 1168. The NLI owns an autograph, that is one of the unique manuscripts written in Maimonides' own hand, of two parts, Nashim, and Mo'ed.

 

This is a page from Seder Mo'ed –"Festival" . Although this is already a "clean" copy, one can see here many changes. The large number of notes and corrections in the autograph, are evidence of  Maimonides' dynamic thinking and constant development.  Maimonides was an original philosopher and thinker who never ceased to ask questions and to improve his works. 

The Commentary remained in the use of the family and in the books in the NLI there are notes which were made by Maimonides' son Abraham, and his grandson David, both of whom were scholars and leaders of the community.

attachments.name: Seder Mo'ed Maimonides, Autograph, Page 72, details.jpg

children.name: :_: What is the Talmud?
children.data:
Talmud (literally "study, learning"), the central text of rabbinic Judaism, has influenced the lives of Jews no less, and perhaps much more than the Hebrew Bible.

For several hundred years, Jewish rabbis in academies in Palestine and in Babyloniastudied the Mishnah. Their discussions were recorded in the Talmud (6th century). These include a wide variety of subjects pertaining to Halakhah (Jewish law) and ethics, philosophy and history, to mention just a few. Jewish scholars thus interpreted the Mishna primarily through the lens of the Talmud. 

The most popular and influential version of the Talmud is the Babylonian one, although a Palestinian version exists as well.

The Talmud, written in Hebrew and Aramaic has become the legal authority in rabbinic Judaism and is the basis for Jewish legal discourse.

 

לאביעד יש רשימה של תלמודים מיוחדים בספרייה

children.name: :_: What is the Mishnah?
children.data:
Alongside the Torah (the Pentateuch), which is the written  law of the Jews,  there developed an oral tradition of interpretation. This tradition was put down in writing and sealed in the beginning of the third century CE by Rabbi Yehudah Ha-Nassi , the head of the Jewish  Assembly, since it was feared at that time that the tradition would be lost. The Mishnah is considered to be a source of religious legal authority second only to the written Torah.

 

photo: A paragraph from the Mishnah, preserved in the Cairo Genizah: "Rabbi Yohanan said: Whoever fulfills the Torah despite poverty, will ultimately fulfill it in wealth; but whoever neglects the Torah because of wealth, will ultimately neglect it in poverty."

attachments.name: Mishnah, Nezikin, Avot, from the Genizah, detail.jpg
attachments.location: F7473840-FD1D-D51D-F9E9-E5C0737401F5\Mishnah, Nezikin, Avot, from the Genizah, detail.jpg

children.name: The language of the Commentary
children.data: The commentary was written in Judeo-Arabic , a dialect of Arabic that was spoken by Jews  living in the Arabic speaking world from the eighth century onwards, and is still spoken by some Jews today.  Although the language was Arabic, it was written in Hebrew letters. Many of the great medieval works of Jewish law and thought were written in Judeo-Arabic.

attachments.name: Learning to read the Hebrew letters in Judeo-Arabic dialect, Yemen.mp3
attachments.location: 7505D43F-518B-4B46-4495-45B81531F2A9\Learning to read the Hebrew letters in Judeo-Arabic dialect, Yemen.mp3

attachments.name: 10th century Jewish Philosophy tractate, Judeo-Arabic, Saʻadiah ben Yosef Gaon Page 1.jpg
attachments.location: 7505D43F-518B-4B46-4495-45B81531F2A9\10th century Jewish Philosophy tractate, Judeo-Arabic, Saʻadiah ben Yosef Gaon Page 1.jpg

children.name: :2: From Egypt to Aleppo
children.data: After Maimonides' death the manuscript remained in the hands of the family in Egypt for several generations. When in 1375, due to the persecutions of Jews in Egypt,  the descendants of Maimonides moved to Aleppo in Syria

children.name: :3: The Library in Aleppo
children.data: The Mishnah Commentary remained in the hands of the family in Aleppo along with other precious manuscripts for several generations.  The family encouraged the Jews in Aleppo to make authorized copies of the manuscripts in the library.

children.name: :4: The arrival of the Spanish Jews and the dispersal of the library
children.data:
With the arrival of the Jews who had been expelled from Spain in 1492, interest in Maimonides' writings declined, and the Spanish Jewish tradition of Kabbalah and mysticism started to  flourish.  By the 17th century the library’s contents had been dispersed .

 

photo:Latin translation of a Kabalah text, Gikatilla's Shaarei Ora

attachments.name: Latin translation of a Kabalah text, Gikatilla's Shaarei Ora.jpg
attachments.location: 1E9B1ED7-FC05-8624-14CD-02272D8B60A1\Latin translation of a Kabalah text, Gikatilla's Shaarei Ora.jpg

children.chronologicalName: The arrival of the Spanish Jews and the dispersal of the library

children.name: :5: From Aleppo to the NLI
children.data:
In the 17th century, when Christian scholars became interested in Hebrew manuscripts, three of the six volumes were purchased in Aleppo by European scholars and were later sold to the Bodleian Library in  Oxford.

 

The other volumes remained  in Aleppo, and then found their way to Damascus. There, two volumes  were found in terrible condition; the  Bodleian Library refused to buy them in this state. Luckily, they were purchased and conserved by the bibliophile Sassoon family from whom they were purchased by the NLI in 1975. 

The sixth volume of the Commentary written Maimonides' own hand is still missing, but perhaps it will one day surface!

attachments.name: Maimonides' Code of Jewish Law at The Bodleian Library
Maimonides at the NLI website - the Great Eagle exhibition

children.name: The Guide of the Perplexed
children.data: The Guide of the Perplexed, an important philosophical treatise, which was composed between 1185-1191, is set as a letter to a young disciple. The Guide sought to resolve apparent contradictions between rationalist philosophy on the one hand, and Jewish tradition found in Scripture and the Talmud, on the other hand.  Unlike the Mishneh Torah, which was written for broad use, the Guide, written in Judeo-Arabic,  was written for a more limited audience of rationalist yet traditional Jews. A few of Maimonides’ theological positions led to public controversies with rabbinic leaders  outside of Egypt towards the end of his life.

attachments.name: Guide of the Preplexed, 14th century, Yemen, Judeo-Arabic, Page 1.jpg
attachments.location: FB6C82E3-22BC-35F8-A367-5AAB2732BB40\Guide of the Preplexed, 14th century, Yemen, Judeo-Arabic, Page 1.jpg

children.name: The  Mishneh Torah
children.data: Following this composition, Maimonides wrote his most famous treatise called the Mishneh Torah, a comprehensive code of Jewish Law which is conceived throughout the Jewish world as one of the chief authoritative codifications of Jewish law and ethics, as well as other important writings. In this great composition Maimonides broke from one thousand years of legal precedent of writing commentaries to produce a systematic codification of Jewish law by subject. Although most of Maimonides’ treatises were written in Judeo-Arabic, Maimonides composed the Code in Hebrew to ensure its accessibility for Jews all over the world.

children.name: The NLI manuscript
children.data: Written between 1300-1350 in Spain, it is the most splendid illuminated copy known. Although copied in Spain, most of the illustrations were done in Perugia  Italy around 1400 in the studio of Matteo di Ser Cambio.

children.name: Maps of The Holy Land at the Eran Laor collection, NLI
children.data:
From ancient times the Holy Land has been the focus of great attraction for both Jews and Christians and Muslims. Throughout the ages Jews and Christians have made pilgrimages to the Holy Land, envisaged scenes and stories from the Scriptures, and dreamt of it from afar. Many of them left behind them descriptions and studies of the Holy Land accompanied by views and drawings.

The Eran Laor map collection in the National Library of Israel contains about 1500 maps of Jerusalem and of the Holy Land from the beginning of print up to our days.

attachments.name: Civitas Hierusalem, Bertelli, Donato, Venice, 16th century [156- ].jpg
Hierusalem, Du Perac, Stefano . Roma, c.1570.jpg

parent.name: The Library as a Memory Deposit: The National Library of Israel

children.name: Christian Maps of the Holy Land
children.data: Depictions of the Holy Land and of Jerusalem appeared mostly in Bibles, in pilgrims' itineraries, in travel books, and in histories and geographies of the Holy Land. Naturally the number of such maps in manuscripts is comparatively small. However, with the invention of the printing press it became worthwhile to produce large and detailed drawings which were then printed often in several editions. These drawings are often called maps, although they were rather drawings or views which were often quite naïve and romantic. Our collection is made up mainly of such maps starting from the end of the 15th century onwards.

attachments.name: Palestinae sive totius Terrae Promissionis, Ortelius, Stella and van Diest, 1575.jpg
attachments.location: AE0BA84A-88FB-0EC6-25D5-BDD81F99F748\Palestinae sive totius Terrae Promissionis, Ortelius, Stella and van Diest, 1575.jpg

parent.name: Maps of The Holy Land at the Eran Laor collection, NLI

children.name: A Journey through Space and Time
children.data: The most striking element about these maps is that often they do not present contemporary realistic depictions as is usually the case with maps of cities or countries. Instead, they can be mostly imaginary, showing for example the land promised to Abraham, or Jerusalem in the time of Jesus; they can also be diachronic, recording traditions and events from the past and the future on one map, often mixing reality with tradition. In this way they share with their readers the experience of this unique site where momentous events occurred and are yet to occur in the future.

attachments.name: Temple of Solomon, 1585, Heinrich Bünting Gestalt des Tempels Salomonis.jpg
attachments.location: AF11075E-6EEC-71E4-6394-9FABE999BD23\Temple of Solomon, 1585, Heinrich Bünting Gestalt des Tempels Salomonis.jpg

parent.name: Christian Maps of the Holy Land

children.name: A Journey to the Holy Land

parent.name: A Journey through Space and Time

children.name: Abraham Ortelius
children.data:
This map was made by the famous publisher, Abraham Ortelius active in the Low Countries during the 16th century who, in an age of great geographical discoveries was the first to print a modern atlas. Although a "modern" cartographer at the time, Ortelius dedicated a special map to "The Life and Peregrination of the Patriarch Abraham to the Promised Land".  

The biblical passage (Genesis 12: 1-2) commanding Abraham to leave on the journey appears along the top frame of the map:  “Go from your country, your people and your father’s household to the land I will show you", while on the bottom appears Genesis 17:8: "The whole land of Canaan, where you now reside as a foreigner, I will give as an everlasting possession to you and your descendants after you ."

attachments.name: Ortelius Cartouch and top biblical passage.jpg

parent.name: A Journey to the Holy Land

children.name: Abraham's stories in the picture emblems
children.data:
The most captivating feature in this map are the picture emblems which tell the story of Abraham:

Abraham's family led by Abraham and his father Terah, are commanded by God to leave Haran for the Promised Land (Genesis 11:31).

children.name: :1: The altar at Beth-El
children.data: After returning to Canaan from Egypt Abraham builds an altar in Beth-El where God appeared to him and promised to give the land to him and to his descendants. (Genesis 13:1-12)

parent.name: Abraham's stories in the picture emblems

children.name: :2: Abraham and Melchizedek
children.data: After defeating the rebellious kings in the Valley of Siddim Abraham (kneeling in his armour) is met by Melchizedek king of Shalem (the future Jerusalem) and priest to the Most High God, who offers him bread and wine and gives him a blessing. (Genesis 14:18-20)

parent.name: Abraham's stories in the picture emblems

children.name: :3: The Covenant of the Parts
children.data: Having promised Abraham as many descendants as the stars, God promises the land to Abraham through theCovenant of the Parts. On the right: God is standing behind Abraham, while Abraham's servant prepares the animals for sacrifice. On the left: the covenant is sealed by a burning torch, the divine fire consuming Abraham's sacrifice. (Genesis 15)

parent.name: Abraham's stories in the picture emblems

children.name: :4: Sarah gives Abraham her slave-girl
children.data: When Sarah despairs of having a child, she gives Abraham her slave-girl so that she may bear him a child. (Genesis 16)

attachments.name: Ortelius Sarah gives Abraham her slave-girl.jpg

parent.name: Abraham's stories in the picture emblems

children.name: :5: The three angels
children.data: Abraham is visited by the three angels. While offering them a place to rest and water to wash  their feet, he is given the surprising tidings that he and Sarah will soon have a child. Sarah is seen in the background preparing the calf. (Genesis 18)

parent.name: Abraham's stories in the picture emblems

children.name: :6: Birth of Isaac
children.data: Sarah is giving birth to Isaac. The new-born baby is being held by the midwife while the maids assist Sarah. (Genesis 21:1-6).

parent.name: Abraham's stories in the picture emblems

children.name: :7: Abraham banishes Hagar and Ishma'el
children.data: After Isaac is born, Abraham sends Hagar away with Ishma'el while the feast in honour of the newborn Isaac is taking place in the background. The protecting angel hovers above the scene. (Genesis 21:8-11)

attachments.name: Ortelius Banishment of Hagar and Ishma'el.jpg

parent.name: Abraham's stories in the picture emblems

children.name: :8: The sacrifice of Isaac
children.data: The Sacrifice of Isaac: on the right Abraham prays asking God to annul this terrible decree, while on the left he is raising the knife when his gaze is guided by the angel towards the ram which he his commanded to offer in Isaac's stead.  (Genesis 22)

parent.name: Abraham's stories in the picture emblems

children.name: :9: Abraham's death
children.data: Abraham's Death: Abraham is being lowered into the grave in the Cave of the Makhpela to be buried beside Sarah. (Genesis 25)

parent.name: Abraham's stories in the picture emblems

children.name: A Dutch Map of the Holy Land
children.data: This map was drawn in the Netherlands, following Ortelius's map of the Holy Land around 1600. The anonymous artist added to Ortelius' map a series of illustrations, including Jonah being tossed to the mouth of the big fish and Israelite figures crossing the desert. At the bottom right the twelve tribes are encamped in the Sinai Desert, and on the bottom right the Grotto of the Nativity in Bethlehem is depicted. Interestingly, the North in the compass rose is pointing to the south!

attachments.name: Palestine, Dutch, beginning of 17th century, 'De Caerte vant theylich land..'.jpg
attachments.location: 0711F4D9-F275-9116-0C43-AE1B48ADAD97\Palestine, Dutch, beginning of 17th century, 'De Caerte vant theylich land..'.jpg

parent.name: A Journey to the Holy Land

children.name: W.J. Blaeu's Map of the Holy Land
children.data: In 1629 W.J. Blaeu printed a new World Atlas containing 45 maps. One of these was the map of the Holy Land or the Promised Land as seen by Moses from Mt. Nevo, after forty years of wandering with the Israelites in the desert, and just before his death. Although the map is focused on Moses, the toponyms reflect the Holy Land from Biblical Times through the Hellenistic and Roman periods in Palestine. The mapmaker strove to draw an accurate map, but at this time both the knowledge and the cartographic skills were still limited.

parent.name: A Journey to the Holy Land

children.name: :1: The Cartouch with the figures of Moses and Aaron
children.data: The Cartouch on the bottom right is surrounded by the figures of Moses and Aaron. Moses, had just descended from Mt. Sinai with the Tablets and is shown according to Jerome's mistaken translation of Exodus 34:29, with horns over his head. Next to him stands Aaron, the High Priest in his special attire and paraphernalia.
children.chronologicalName: The Cartouch with the figures of Moses and Aaron

parent.name: W.J. Blaeu's Map of the Holy Land

children.name: :2: The Wanderings of the Children of Israel in the desert
children.data: The story of Moses and the Wanderings of the Children of Israel in the desert is shown here in miniature drawings: on the left the Children of Israel are seen crossing the parted Red Sea, their following route through the desert being marked by a yellow trail. On the right the revelation at Mount Sinai, as well as the Tabernacle and the various camps of the Israelites are depicted.
children.chronologicalName: The Wanderings of the Children of Israel in the desert

parent.name: W.J. Blaeu's Map of the Holy Land

children.name: Mattheus Seutter's Map of the Holy Land
children.data: Matthaeus Seutter's map of Palestine, was part of his atlas, which was popular in Europe in the 18th century. The map, based on a prototype made a century earlier by Sanson, aims to depict to the Christian European audience the Holy Land from its beginning until the Roman period, covering the period of the events told in the Old and New Testament. Not less important than the map is the scene on the top left, showing Jesus exorcising a demon, watched from above by God and the Holy Spirit, and Crucifixion in the background. On the bottom right the route of the  Exodus from Egypt is depicted separately.

parent.name: A Journey to the Holy Land

children.name: A Journey to Biblical Jerusalem
children.data: Christians throughout the ages were drawn to Jerusalem, captivated by its glorious past: it was the city into which according to Christian tradition Jesus made his Triumphal Entry, the stage upon which the events of the Great Week took place, and the place of his Crucifixion and Resurrection and the Ascension. It was also the city of David and Solomon and the setting of a multitude of biblical events. Although many pilgrims and scholars purported to depict "modern" Jerusalem, their maps often followed much earlier maps, and their main aim was to map out the Christian sites, usually ignoring the Muslim presence in the city.

parent.name: A Journey through Space and Time

children.name: Christian van Adrichom's Map of Jerusalem in the Time of Jesus (1590)
children.data: Christian van Adrichom was a Catholic priest and theologian who was a native of Delft, who fled to Cologne due to the religious turmoils of the Reformation. His map of Jerusalem is part of his book on the antiquities and history of the Holy Land which was published in 1584. The map is an imaginary map which is based on the texts he was familiar with, including the Bible, Josephus Flavius, and many other sources and has little relation to the geographical setting of the city. Although it depicts Jerusalem in the time of Jesus, it includes a variety of illustrations from sundry historical periods. Adrichom's map was one of the most popular and influential maps of the period and was copied by many.

children.name: Biblical Scenes in Adrichom's map
children.data: Biblical Scenes are represented widely in Adrichom's map:

parent.name: Christian van Adrichom's Map of Jerusalem in the Time of Jesus (1590)

children.name: :1: King David's palace
children.data: The palace of King David and above it Bathsheba, the future mother of King Solomon, bathing on the roof near the palace.

children.name: :2: King Solomon's palace and the First Temple
children.data: King Solomon's palace and the First Temple are depicted in detail: The Temple Courtyard drawn according to Josephus' description, the Ark and the Cherubim, the High Priest, the Candelabrum and the Table of the Showbread, and the Sacrificial Altar in front of the  Temple.
children.chronologicalName: King Solomon's palace and the First Temple

children.name: :3: The shrine of the idol Moloch
children.data: The Temple of the Ammonite idol Moloch which king Solomon built in the Valley of Gehena (I Kings: 11:7).  According to the Bible (I Kings 16:3; 21:6), the kings of Judah Ahaz and Manasseh  took part in the Moloch ritual by passing their sons in the fire. Below the sawing of the tree where the Prophet Isaiah hid by the slaves of the wicked king Manasseh, and Isaiah's sepulcher.
children.chronologicalName: The shrine of the idol Moloch

children.name: :4: The Babylonian army camp
children.data: The camp of the Babylonian army besieging Jerusalem on the eve of the destruction of the First Temple.

children.name: The Via Dolorosa as depicted in Adrichom's map
children.data: The Via Dolorosa of Jesus, from his trial by Pilate to his Crucifixion is depicted in detail in Adrichom's map.

parent.name: Christian van Adrichom's Map of Jerusalem in the Time of Jesus (1590)

children.name: :1: The Antonia fortress and Pilate's palace
children.data: The Antonia fortress and Pilate's palace where the Trial of Jesus takes place and Pilate declares: "Crucifige".
children.chronologicalName: The Antonia fortress and Pilate's palace

parent.name: The Via Dolorosa as depicted in Adrichom's map

children.name: :2: The Via Dolorosa
children.data: The Via Dolorosa – Jesus is commanded to carry the Cross, he falls, and is then assisted by Simon of Cyrene.

parent.name: The Via Dolorosa as depicted in Adrichom's map

children.name: :3: The Crucifixion
children.data: The Crucifixion along with the two thieves, the two Marys standing under the cross, Jesus being taken down from the Cross and buried, and the Resurrection.

parent.name: The Via Dolorosa as depicted in Adrichom's map

children.name: Braun and Hogenberg's map of Jerusalem
children.data: This view of Jerusalem was one of three maps of the city included in the famous city atlas compiled by Braun and Hoghenberg in 1575. The city is seen here in the eyes of pilgrims when standing on the Mount of Olives, looking eastwards. Although the round shape of the city is schematic, there are various realistic elements such as the citadel in the background, the bridges over the Kidron valley and the blocked doorway to the church of the Holy Sepulchre. Ezek. 5:5 at the top conveys the idea of Jerusalem as the center of the earth, while the citation from Pliny the Elder on the bottom left lauds "Jerusalem, the most famous of the cities in the Orient, Metropolis of Judaea".

attachments.name: Jerusalem, Hogenberg, Braun and Jansson, Amsterdam, 1657.jpg

children.name: Jerusalem under Ottoman Rule
children.data: This view made by L. Mondhare in 1770 portrays Ottoman Jerusalem as a city commanded by towering minarets and crescents in a surreal mixture of imagination and reality. Prominently situated towards the left of the map is the Dome of the Rock while in the center the Church of the Holy Sepulcher stands out clearly. At the front of the sketch is the Kidron River, appearing as a broad, rushing, European style river, attesting to the artist's vivid imagination. The inscription at the bottom states that the City of David and Solomon is currently controlled by the Ottomans and notes the existence of a Franciscan monastery within the city.

attachments.name: Jerusalem, Mondhare, Paris 1770, 'Jerusalem Ville Capitale de la Palestine sous David et Salomon'.jpg
attachments.location: F1A2E200-3903-B57D-F9ED-561C9A606EB0\Jerusalem, Mondhare, Paris 1770, 'Jerusalem Ville Capitale de la Palestine sous David et Salomon'.jpg

children.name: Jean François Daumont's Map
children.data:
Jean François Daumont made this beautiful map of Jerusalem in 1780, yet it was made after a map originally drawn almost 300 years beforehand,  in 1486, following the pilgrimage of Bernhard of Breydenbach to Jerusalem in 1483.

Daumont chooses to identify Christian and Muslim monuments by a Cross or Crescent, but does not name the Muslim monuments. Daumont chooses to call the mosques on the Temple Mount in fact by their Crusader name: "Templum Salomonis".

children.name: Olfert Dapper's map of Jerusalem
children.data:
Dapper (1635-1689), who never travelled outside Holland, collected much information about the Holy Land and many other countries. His realistic map (1677) relied on a Bernardino Amico's map who was a Franciscan monk in Jerusalem between 1593-1597. Amico, in his turn, copied a map made by the Franciscan monk Antonio d'Angelis who had served in Jerusalem a few years before; his map continued to be copied by generations of Christian map-makers.

The map does not identify the religious affiliation of the monuments by a Cross or Crescent, and calls the Mosques on the Temple Mount – "The Pagan Church".

attachments.name: Jerusalem, Dapper, Amsterdam 1677 'De Stadt Ierusalem zoot Hedendaeghs Bevonden wordt'.jpg
attachments.location: 62CF2583-19FF-9B73-7ED2-2E3C833E1F7F\Jerusalem, Dapper, Amsterdam 1677 'De Stadt Ierusalem zoot Hedendaeghs Bevonden wordt'.jpg

children.name: The Land of Israel in Jewish Eyes
children.data: Jewish maps, though not very many, represent the centrality of the Land of Israel in the history of the Jewish people and in their hopes. Traditional Jewish maps reflect two distinct trends in cartographic tradition: one group of maps follows  the original maps made by the prominent Bible commentator Rashi, while another follows Christian map models adapted to Jewish notions.

attachments.name: Map of The Land Israel, Showing the Wanderings of the Israelites in the Desert and Allotments of the Tribes, Abraham ben Jacob, 17th cent.jpg

children.name: The Land of Israel and its Borders in Biblical Times – the  Jewish Tradition
children.data:
This lovely hand-drawn map was created in the 19th century by an artist who claims that he copied it from the famous Jewish scholar, the Vilna Gaon (1720-1797).

The map follows an ancient tradition of mapping the borders of Land of Israel, as described in Numbers 34. This tradition commenced with Rashi, the greatest Jewish commentator of the Bible, who lived in France in the 11th century.

Later tradition added the allotments of the 12 tribes, and cities and settlements which are represented here as European houses with tiled roofs. Jerusalem is depicted prominently with a tower beside it bearing the inscription "The Temple".

attachments.name: Palestine, biblical borders and allotments of the tribes of Israel, mid nineteenth century.jpg
attachments.location: 6D3C4593-7543-E128-8DAC-F2605F00061D\Palestine, biblical borders and allotments of the tribes of Israel, mid nineteenth century.jpg

parent.name: The Land of Israel in Jewish Eyes

children.name: European Currents: Shlomo of Helm's Map of the Land of Israel
children.data:
R. Shlomo of Helm (1717-1781) was a famous Jewish scholar and Rabbi in Poland. Although he was famous for his erudition in Jewish sources and law (Halakha), he chose extraordinarily to emphasize the importance of the study of Philosophy and Sciences alongside Jewish studies.

In the autograph manuscript of his book "Hug Ha-Aretz", recently purchased by the NLI, written in beautiful classical Hebrew language and in handsome calligraphic script, R. Shlomo drew a series of maps of the Land of Israel divided among the Tribes. Unlike the tradition following Rashi's maps, the legends in his maps prove that he was clearly inspired by the Christian maps of the Holy Land made by Adrichom and by Seutter.

parent.name: The Land of Israel in Jewish Eyes

children.name: Newton's Theological Papers
children.data:
Isaac Newton (1642-1727), the a world-famous   physicist and mathematician, was a central figure in the scientific revolution.

7500 papers, written in Newton's own hand, are preserved in the collections of the National Library of Israel. These divulge an unknown side of Newton's personality. Besides being a scientist, Newton was an avid (though unusual) Christian believer, who took  a special interest in the Scriptures, believing that a deep understanding of the text will allow him to unravel the secrets of the end of days and to compute the date of  Christ's Second Coming and the Apocalypse. Of special importance is Newton's deep interest in  the Jewish sources, and his view regarding the role they of the Jews  in the process of salvation.

attachments.name: Newton, treatise on the origin of religion and its corruption.jpg
attachments.location: A9033D67-7C48-B1E8-59A7-6F4E372E0EA7\Newton, treatise on the origin of religion and its corruption.jpg

parent.name: The Library as a Memory Deposit: The National Library of Israel

children.name: :1: 2060 – The End of Days
children.data: In these notes, written on a letter bearing the remnants of its red seal wax, Newton calculated, based on the Book of Daniel 7:25, that the end of time will arrive in the year 2060.  Newton's calculations relied on his belief that the starting point is the year 800, a time when Charlemagne founded the Holy Roman Empire and the Pope's supremacy commenced. Here, Newton believed,  began the period of the "apostate's" church deepest corruption which will end in the Apocalyptic events such as plagues and fires, the terrible battle of Armageddon and eternal damnation of the wicked mentioned in the  Book of Revelation.

children.name: :2: Newton the Heretic
children.data:
Newton's extensive study of the Christian Doctrine brought him to the conclusion that the doctrine of the Trinity was a corruption of the original biblical doctrine. He believed that the Scriptures taught that God is one person and that this one person is the Father, while Christ is the literal Son of God, having no human father.

Newton hid his beliefs. Had his contemporaries known of them he would have been considered a heretic. He however, believed that he was the true Orthodox.

 

 

On the Photograph

Par. 1 - The [word] God is no where in the scriptures used to signify more than the three persons at once.

Par. 3 – When ever it is said in the scriptures that there is but one God, it is meant of the Father.

attachments.name: Isaac Newton, Rejector of the Trinity

children.name: :3: Newton and the Jewish Temple
children.data:
Newton believed that the temple described in the prophecy of Ezekiel will materialize at the End of Days. He therefore invested much effort in studying matters related to the Jewish Temple and its rituals.

This trilingual manuscript written in Latin, Hebrew and Greek shows that Newton was familiar not only with the work of  scholars of his time but also with the ancient Jewish       sources including the Mishna , the Zohar, the Talmud, and many more.

On the third line from the top Newton copied in meticulous Hebrew script the words:

ברוך שם כבוד מלכותו לעולם ועד  - " - Blessed be the name of His glorious kingdom for all eternity".

attachments.name: Fragments on the kingdoms of the European tribes, the Temple and the history of Jewish and Christian Churches (sec. 5) 28e002v.jpg
attachments.location: 4130AC26-0B7C-306D-58D1-87B4DD7C00BD\Fragments on the kingdoms of the European tribes, the Temple and the history of Jewish and Christian Churches (sec. 5) 28e002v.jpg

children.name: :_: The Talmud
children.data:
Talmud, the central text of rabbinic Judaism has influenced the lives of Jews no less, and perhaps much more than the Hebrew Bible. The Talmud (literally "study, learning") contains the teachings, the discussions and opinions of rabbis on a variety of subjects pertaining to Halakhah (Jewish law) and ethics, philosophy and history, to mention just a few.

The talmudic text, also known as Gemara (literally: tradition) is based on discussions which took place in Jewish academies between the third and the sixth centuries, in Palestine and in Babylonia. These discussions usually revolve around the Mishnah which was assembled in the beginning of the third century. The most popular and influential version of the Talmud is the Babylonian one, although a Palestinian version exists as well.

The Talmud, written in Hebrew and Aramaic has become the legal authority in rabbinic Judaism and is the basis for halakhic discourse. Maimonides' Mishneh Torah is a legal code summarizing Jewish law and is based mainly on the Talmud.

children.name: :4: Map of the Fifth and Sixth Trumpets
children.data:
Newton's preoccupation with the Apocalypse of John elicited this realistic map of the Near East which illustrates the geography of the region in which the Apocalyptic events will occur. According to Revelation 9 four angels will be released on the Euphrates river and will punish the sinners. Newton believed that the Fifth Trumpet is Islam, and the Sixth – the Ottoman Empire and identified as these four angels in the Sultanates marked out on the map: Iconium, Damascus, Mosul and Miapharekin,.

children.name: :5: Newton -  Shrewd Head of the Royal Mint
children.data:
Besides being a brilliant scientist and theologian, Newton was also displayed adroit skills as an administrator. In 1696 He was appointed Warden of the Royal Mint in London. In this capacity Newton wrote this letter to the tin mine owners, explaining to them through meticulous calculations that Her Majesty, Queen Anne, has already purchased from them much more tin than she can sell, leaving her with "dead stock" (surplus), which can only be sold at a loss.

He therefore announces his decision to end the contract with them.
children.chronologicalName: Newton -  Shrewd Head of the Royal Mint

children.name: :6: Newton the Alchemist (c. 1680)
children.data: Newton also took a deep interest in Alchemy. Although most of the Alchemical papers are in Cambridge, the NLI possesses one unique page. It is a part of Newton's copy of an English translation made in 1624 of the Exposition of the Hieroglyphical figures written by the famous French Alchemist Nicholas Flamel. Newton sketched Flamel's symbolic figures, and described in the text above  their Alchemical role.

children.name: Journey of Newton's Papers: from Cambridge to the NLI

parent.name: Journey of Newton's Papers: from Cambridge to the NLI

children.name: :1: Descent
children.data:
Abraham Shalom Yahuda (1877 – 1951) was born in Jerusalem to a respectable family. His father's family, which had arrived in Jerusalem from Baghdad,  descended from the famous Yosef ben Shushan, a Jewish minister at the court of Alfonso VIII (1155-1214), king of Castile while his mother came from a  well-known German Jewish family

 

photo: The Tolledo synagogue built by Yosef Ben-Shushan's son, one of A.S. Yahuda's forefathers. The Synagogue was later converted into a church by the name of Santa Maria la Blanca.

children.name: :2: Education
children.data: From a very young age Yahuda mastered both Jewish studies as well as the Arabic language and other European languages. He specialized in classical Arabic literature and at age 17 he already published a book on the subject. He then continued his studies in Germany with important scholars in the field of Arabic and Islamic history.

children.name: :3: From Madrid to Europe and the East
children.data: Between  1914-1922 Yahuda served as professor in Madrid. (In later years Yahuda wrote memoirs in Hebrew describing  his sojourn in Spain.) He then left Spain, and spent the years between 1922 and 1942 travelling all over Europe and the East. During these years Yahuda acquired many rare manuscripts and traded in them. Yahuda's great erudition in many fields, and especially in Islam, explains the superior manuscripts that he chose to acquire during his travels.
children.chronologicalName: From Madrid to Europe and the East

children.name: :4: America
children.data: In 1942 Yahuda received a position in the New School of Social Research in New-York, and from then on, until his death in 1951, spent most of his time on his research.

children.name: :5: The Yahuda Exquisite Manuscript Collection Islamic manuscripts
children.data:
Yahuda bequeathed to the National Library of Israel  1184 exquisite eastern manuscripts in the field of Islamic religion, sciences, Arabic literature and Persian poetry. These include a unique collection of  over 100 rare manuscripts of the Qur'an, some very early ones (8th-10th centuries), and others which are beautifully illustrated.

 

Jewish manuscripts

  • Yahuda's collection of Jewish manuscripts includes the most beautiful existing manuscript of  Maimonides' Mishneh Torah
  • and documents of the Jewish Community in Aragon, including a Privilege granted by King Alfonso V of Aragon  (1416-1438) to the nobleman Berenguer de Bardaxi , granting him permission to settle 30-40 Jewish families on his lands in Oliete, south of Saragossa.

Other Manuscripts

Besides Newton's theological papers, the collection includes beautiful Books of Hours, letters of Napoleon Bonaparte, and many more.  ספר השעות; מכתב של נפוליאון
children.chronologicalName: The Yahuda Exquisite Manuscript Collection Islamic manuscripts

children.name: :1: Newton's Papers  - from 1727 to 1872
children.data: Upon Newton's death in Cambridge in 1727, his relatives, the Conduitts, claimed his papers. Newton's papers reflected an array of various interests and occupations: papers in Mathematics and Physics,  documents written as part of his function as head of the Royal Mint and President of the Royal Society, and  the less known and more intriguing papers on Theology ,History and Alchemy.

parent.name: Journey of Newton's Papers: from Cambridge to the NLI

children.name: :2: Donation of the Papers to Cambridge  - 1872 – 1936
children.data:
In 1872, one of Newton's descendants, the 5th Earl of Portsmouth, donated the papers to the University of Cambridge, in which Newton had studied and taught. The committee appointed by the University to review the papers, selected only Newton's scientific papers, not wanting to blemish his reputation as an enlightened intellectual and scientist.

The theological papers, as well as the alchemical and the historical papers were returned to the family.

parent.name: Journey of Newton's Papers: from Cambridge to the NLI

children.name: :3: July 13th 1936 – The Papers are Sold
children.data: In July 1936 the papers which had been given back to the family were put up for sale by Sotheby's in London. The sale was poorly attended since at the same time, in London, Impressionist paintings were being sold at Christie's! Newton's papers were thus sold to a variety of people for the mere some of 9000 pounds.

parent.name: Journey of Newton's Papers: from Cambridge to the NLI

children.name: :4: 1936 – 1951 – Yahuda and Keynes Chase after the Papers
children.data: Having found out belatedly about the sale, two important scholars were resolved to purchase the papers. The first was the famous British economist, John Maynard Keynes, who strove to buy all the alchemical papers; the second was the Jerusalem born well-known Orientalist, Abraham Shalom Yahuda. At some point, they even exchanged some of the papers between them!

parent.name: Journey of Newton's Papers: from Cambridge to the NLI

children.name: :5: 1951 –Bequest of the Papers
children.data:
While the Alchemical papers, acquired by Keynes, were bequeathed by him to Cambridge upon his death in 1946, A.S. Yahuda bequeathed his papers upon his death in 1951 to the National Library of Israel in Jerusalem, along with many other important and beautiful manuscripts of all sorts.

Newton's Theological Papers were bequeathed by A.S. Yahuda  to the library along with many other important Jewish, Muslim and Christian manuscripts (these include outstanding Muslim manuscripts – here is a short glimpse).
